awd_titl_txt: High-field Dynamic Nuclear Polarization using Spin Probes and Intrinsic Defects at Local Interfaces of Polymers and Solids
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program in the Division of Chemistry, Prof. Song-I Han and her group at the University of California - Santa Barbara are developing new instrumentation and methodologies for high magnetic field nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) to probe the detailed microstructure of complex and heterogeneous materials, e.g. of multiphase block copolymers or amorphous silicon. The sensitivity of conventional NMR spectroscopy is insufficient to probe the microstructural properties at the surface or interface at the necessary sub-nanometer length scale. Prof. Han addresses this challenge by developing novel dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP)-amplified NMR instrumentation and methods at 7 Tesla that enhance signals by up to five orders of magnitudes through cryogenic cooling and polarization transfer from polarized electron spins to nuclear spins. A unique and crucial aspect of the approach is utilization of strategic electron spin probes specifically located through chemical functionalization, or intrinsic paramagnetic defects that are critical to the function or malfunction of the materials. Prof. Han is adding concurrent continuous wave and pulsed electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) detection capabilities to a home-built spectrometer to provide complete materials characterization through the nuclear and electron spin probes. 

The high field DNP approach may have high impact on the study of a wide range of functional and heterogeneous materials, e.g. a variety of multiphase polymer systems or amorphous and crystalline Si based photovoltaic materials, whose interfacial properties or intrinsic paramagnetic centers lie at the core of their function or malfunction. Educational impact is enhanced by provision of research opportunities for undergraduate students and by supporting professional development for women scientists pursuing high level science careers.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn: Summary. This project focused on the development of high-field dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP) instrumentation, methodology and application. Our development relies on a home-built DNP instrument based on a 7 Tesla NMR magnet that is powered by a solid-state diode microwave source tunable between 193 and 201 GHz, controlled by a quasi-optics bridge and operates at high down to liquid helium temperatures. Intellectual Merit. The science goal was focused on using selective spin probes that are labeled or imbibed to specific surfaces or regions of heterogeneous materials to obtain surface and region specific information about the materials from selectively enhanced NMR information. The project outcome was three-fold. First, a DNP instrument with high and robust performance, as well as dual DNP and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) operation has been built, tested and completed. Second, significant insight into DNP mechanisms was gained, in particular that multi-electron spin coupling of proximal spins play an important role in EPR saturation and polarization transfer, such that optimal DNP performance can be obtained with simple mono nitroxide radical based spin probes. This is crucial for the prospect of employing tailored radical spin probes, as the local electron spin concentration can be tuned to achieve the same DNP performance as designer biradicals that are non-trivial to chemically modify. Third, it has been demonstrated that selectively incorporated mono nitroxide radical pin probes can be used for selective DNP enhancement of heterogeneous catalyst model and membrane surfaces in the vicinity of the spin probe. This will become particularly meaningful once the spin probe can be tailored to mimic reactants in chemical reaction or catalyst systems. Broader impact. The dual 7 Tesla DNP/EPR instrumentation developed in this study is currently not available in other laboratories. The demonstration of the merit and prospect of an alternative DNP approach with the here supported studies will contribute to the broader interest in versatile DNP and dual DNP/EPR technology. We expect this study to spur the development of similar capabilities in other laboratories. New instrumental capabilities will generate new applications. We expect the impact of our development to go beyond the science goal as pursued in our project, and includes the study of advanced materials properties at low temperatures, catalyst materials and battery applications, to name a f...
por.por_txt_cntn:
Summary. This project focused on the development of                       high-field dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP)                       instrumentation, methodology and application. Our                       development relies on a home-built DNP instrument                       based on a 7 Tesla NMR magnet that is powered by a                       solid-state diode microwave source tunable between                       193 and 201 GHz, controlled by a quasi-optics                       bridge and operates at high down to liquid                       helium temperatures.                       Intellectual                           Merit. The science goal was                       focused on using selective spin probes that are                       labeled or imbibed to specific surfaces or regions                       of heterogeneous materials to obtain surface and                       region specific information about the materials                       from selectively enhanced NMR information. The                       project outcome was three-fold. First, a DNP                       instrument with high and robust performance, as                       well as dual DNP and electron paramagnetic                       resonance (EPR) operation has been built, tested                       and completed. Second, significant insight into                       DNP mechanisms was gained, in particular that                       multi-electron spin coupling of proximal spins                       play an important role in EPR saturation and                       polarization transfer, such that optimal DNP                       performance can be obtained with simple mono                       nitroxide radical based spin probes. This is                       crucial for the prospect of employing tailored                       radical spin probes, as the local electron spin                       concentration can be tuned to achieve the same DNP                       performance as designer biradicals that are                       non-trivial to chemically modify. Third, it has                       been demonstrated that selectively incorporated                       mono nitroxide radical pin probes can be used for                       selective DNP enhancement of heterogeneous                       catalyst model and membrane surfaces in the vicinity of                       the spin probe. This will become particularly                       meaningful once the spin probe can be tailored to                       mimic reactants in chemical reaction or catalyst                       systems.                       Broader                           impact. The dual 7 Tesla                       DNP/EPR instrumentation developed in this study is                       currently not available in other laboratories. The demonstration of the merit and prospect of an alternative DNP                       approach with the here supported studies will contribute to the broader interest in versatile DNP and dual DNP/EPR technology. We expect this                       study to spur the development of similar                       capabilities in other laboratories. New                       instrumental capabilities will generate new                       applications. We expect the impact of our                       development to go beyond the science goal as                       pursued in our project, and includes the study of                       advanced materials properties at low temperatures,                       catalyst materials and battery applications, to                       name a few.
